newsitem.title: UK: WORLDWIDE ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST - AUGUST 12.
newsitem.headline: WORLDWIDE ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST - AUGUST 12.

text.p: ....REUTERS WORLDWIDE ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST.....
Reuters news from around the world on Advertising, Marketing, Media, the Internet, Brand-name Products and Consumer Trends
ADVERTISING & MARKETING:

CHICAGO - Global advertising company True North Communications Inc. says it earned $7.2 million, or 30 cents a share, in the second quarter, compared with $6.0 million, or 26 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago, a 19 percent increase.

LONDON - Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising has formed a new marketing company in the U.S. Darwin Digital, which began as Saatchi & Saatchi Interactive in 1994, is dedicated to shaping the longterm growth of the interactive industry and digital marketing opportunities.

PARIS - Britain's Virgin Group, aiming to snatch the number two slot from Pepsico's Pepsi Cola in France, is running a series of spoof adverts this month to coincide with the launch of Virgin Cola on the French market.

BOCA RATON, Florida - Florida kicks off a promotional campaign for its $32 billion tourism industry, introducing a new name and logo for its chief booster agency. The Florida Tourism Industry Marketing Corporation has changed its name to "Visit Florida Inc".
LONDON - DDB International, part of the U.S.-based DDB Needham advertising agency network, says it has expanded its Middle East network by joining forces with Idea Advertising Ltd in Amman, Jordan.
MEDIA & THE INTERNET:

NEW YORK - The U.S. radio broadcasting industry is booming following mergers and acquisitions, strategic efforts to take advantage of de-regulation and more intensive local exposure. Advertisers like Bozell Worldwide are getting in on the act with promotions aiming to establish brand identities for individual stations which guarantee audience segments.

WELLINGTON - A survey of New Zealand Internet usage by AC Nielsen McNair shows a surge in access to and usage of the Internet. In the first quarter of 1997, 32 percent of New Zealanders aged 10 or over had access to the Internet at some location compared with 16 percent a year ago, the survey says.

BERLIN - Berlin-based radio station RS2 says it hopes to repeat the success that U.S. and British radio stations have seen with a heavier regional focus by starting three separate broadcasts for a neighbouring state. RS2 will spend 1.5 million marks ($804,000) on local shows and plans to earn that back in advertising revenues next year, says programming director Rik De Lisle.
JAKARTA - Indonesia's only pay television company is racing ahead with plans to put up its own satellite and will have 40 digital channels by the end of the year, officials say.

LONDON - The use of corporate intranets is growing at an explosive pace in Britain's financial sector, according to Datamonitor, a market research group. The number of personal computers in the UK financial sector linked to intranets is expected to shoot up to 429,000 by the year 2001 from a present 96,000.
BRAND-NAME PRODUCTS & MARKETS:

MUNICH - A study of brand-name products in Germany shows a direct relationship between the amount of money a company spends on ads and its success in the market. "The higher the media budget of a brand name is, the more successful it is," MediaGruppe Muenchen, a media marketing firm, says.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland - Hibernia Beer, launched in May to mark the christening of the platform for Canada's first major offshore oil project, is in huge demand, with almost 20,000 dozen bottles sold so far. The brew is currently only sold in Newfoundland, but the Quidi Vidi Brewing Co plans to make the lager a permanent product.
COLOMBO - Sri Lankans are drinking more beer since the excise duty was slashed last November, with beer consumption up 40 percent.

SINGAPORE - Goldsmiths in Singapore are working 18 or 19 hours a day to satisfy the explosive demand for jewelry following July's sharp fall in the price of gold to 12-year lows of around US$314 an ounce.

LONDON - Coffee has overtaken tea in the UK hot drinks market, market research group Datamonitor reports. Coffee has grown at a rate of 11 percent a year since 1992 and now accounts for the largest share of the UK hot drinks market.

BONN - Intel Corp is preparing for a new manufacturing process that should produce tens of millions of chips that will eventually be four times faster than the chips in today's top-selling personal computers.
CONSUMER TRENDS:

MACAU - Portuguese-governed Macau announces a sharp drop in tourism coinciding with a wave of violence linked to triad gangster wars. The number of guests at Macau hotels shrank 23.3 percent in June from the year-earlier period, the Statistics and Census Department says.

SHANGHAI - The people of Shanghai, China's richest city, are spending one billion yuan ($120.6 million) a year on pets that include squirrels, yellow-skinned wolves and insects, and are developing a taste for electronic Tamagotchi pets too, Business News says. The market for live pets is now 10 times the size it was a decade ago, the newspaper says.

LONDON - The introduction of a single European currency will create both winners and losers in Europe's travel industry but will encourage overall growth in tourism, a survey by the Centre for Economics and Business Research says.
